content.description: <math alttext="4 F e solid plus 3 O 2 gas is in equilibrium with 2 F e 2 O 3 solid. delta H equals negative 1650 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>1,650</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The oxidation of <math alttext="F e solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the chemical equation above. Which of the following correctly explains whether or not the reaction is thermodynamically favorable?

choices.label: There are more particles (including particles in the gas state) in the reactants than in the product, thus <math alttext="delta S of reaction is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Because <math alttext="delta H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large and negative, the reaction will be thermodynamically favorable at low temperatures.

There are more particles (including particles in the gas state) in the reactants than in the product, thus <math alttext="delta S of reaction is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Because <math alttext="delta H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large and negative, the reaction will be not be thermodynamically favorable at any temperature.

There are more particles (including particles in the gas state) in the reactants than in the product, thus <math alttext="delta S of reaction is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Because <math alttext="delta H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large and negative, the reaction will be thermodynamically favorable at all temperatures.

There are more particles (including particles in the gas state) in the reactants than in the product, thus <math alttext="delta S of reaction is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Because <math alttext="delta H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large and negative, the reaction will be not be thermodynamically favorable at any temperature.

content.answer: There are more particles (including particles in the gas state) in the reactants than in the product, thus <math alttext="delta S of reaction is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Because <math alttext="delta H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is large and negative, the reaction will be thermodynamically favorable at low temperatures.

topic.text: 9.3: Gibbs Free Energy and Thermodynamic Favorability

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
